author: cian riordan
content:
Aside from the usual discussion about headphone preferences and HRTF, I’ll give you my experience with them.

I bought them a few years ago with the intention of just having a baller set of headphones for a bunch of travel I had coming up. I had tried them once at @oaklandmatt’s place and wasn’t super impressed... just thought they sounded like hyped headphones. But I really wanted something with killer noise cancellation and something to potentially reference Spatial mixes. After purchasing, the more I used them, the more I fell in love with listening to music on them. I realized quite early on that there was a lot of parity between how things sounded in the APMaxes vs. my PMC 6-2s… similar low end presentation, similar high end. But just genuinely enjoyed listening to music on them.

I was traveling for thanksgiving last year and a last minute mix opportunity came up for some video game trailer. Not my normal speed but they were up shits creek with a deadline and the money was good… so I mixed the whole thing start to finish on my laptop with the Airpods. I was a little sheepish about sending off un-vetted mixes, but the clients loved it and I saved the day. I curiously took a listen when I got back to my studio after the holiday and was very surprised that the mix was 98% there. There was maybe a small low end tweak I could’ve made, but by and large, the mixes translated incredibly well. 

Now I use them much more for odd tasks, usually revisions and printing sessions. I can be on my couch on my laptop running files down with transparency mode on, still hanging with my family while watching a show, and lock in with noise cancelling when I need to focus.

For $600 they’ve been a massive value-add to my work flow.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So obviously starting with the right bass is going to get you 70% of the way there, but you know what *really* surprised the hell out of me? The *strings*. 

If you're not getting anywhere close to the tone that you want, start exploring the wide world of bass strings. I had overlooked this simple thing for ages. I took my choice of strings for granted because I never had to change them. And when I did it made all of the difference in my tone.

I've always been a Fender guy: P-basses and J-Basses, and the DI signal was always voiced way too dark to pop out of a mix without some heavy lifting. Granted I also use flatwounds (which aren't as zippy as roundwounds). 

After some research on the TalkBass forum, I ordered a few different sets of flats to experiment. One such set were the *Thomastik-Infeld Jazz Flats*, and ho-lee *shit*. There it was. There was the sound I was looking for.

They were voiced way lighter in the bass, which gave me a far more articulate midrange. Like the sound of an upright bass which (trust me) is a very good quality to have unless you're going for a grindy metal tone. As it turns out, the midrange is where *all* of the action is in the bass. It's okay if your bass DI is voiced with no low-end, because you can always add that weight back in, but if the midrange is not present to begin with it is an uphill battle to make it articulate in a mix.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I've been a "musician" since way before i started recording and producing stuff. (Since i was 4 i think). It's such an integral part of how music can feel and make you move. Think about how someone like Anderson paak. can make you dance by just playing 8th notes on a highhat and nothing else(see tinydesk for ref.) or Pino Paladino, will make you break your neck with his bass, playing simple Quater notes. (anything D'angelo).  Even in a genre that is as quantized and on the grid as it gets like a lot of hiphop/trap is, notice how the artist(rappers) that really stand out, are the ones that make those beats really groove/hit because of how they themselves "groove" or flow on those beats. They might be slightly behind or in front of the beat, or they might even swing a little. 

You can really get into the micro and macro dynamics of groove. Listen to guys like Led zeppelin, how they might start out a song a few BPM slower than they finish, because of the build up of energy through out the song, and it doesn't sound wrong or unnatural. 

A fun thing to do, when looking for inspiration for grooves, is record some foley, and look for naturally occurring rhythms in the sample. Try and build a grove around that probably a bit wonky rhythm. It can really be an eye opening experience once you realise how much fun rhythm and groove is, when you don't have to obey the grid in a daw like a machine. 

But like anything music, it's really about listening and feeling. Really internalising what a forward or laid back snare feels like or a bass thats almost a 16th behind the beat.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Peeps making Reese bases themselves in serum. 

When you’ve made the sound how you want you’ll often find with stereo Reese bases the fundamental is phasing in and out so your low end isn’t very consistent. 

What you can do is go into the waveform editor on the oscillators and click “remove fundamental” then enable the separate sub Osc and set it to direct out. That way you get a nice consistent fundamental, but your harmonics are still moving giving you that classic Reese sound but with a much beefier stable low end. 

Hit my DM if anyone needs me to be more specific 😇

author: Slow Hand
content:
Granted, her examples are *very* specific to orchestra and not directly applicable to pop records, but the underlying principles here include:

**1) **Think of instrument combinations as a single composite voice.

One instrument can function as the "sustain" portion of the sound and a second instrument gives the "attack". Together they create a single melodic voice.

**2) **How do the instruments stack on each other? Do they clash? Cellos doubling a bass an octave up extend it's timbre into a higher register to make it read better. It's not so different from adding fuzz to an 808 so that it has more presence.

**3) **Which instrument will cut through the music?

---

A few concepts that I'll add:

**4) **Instruments in the foreground vs. the background. Know which part is the lead (focal point) at any given point in the record and then pare down the presence of the rest and push it into the back of the sound stage.

**5)** (Piggybacking off of Felix's excellent post) What is the simplest way to achieve the desired effect? Reduce. Reduce. Reduce.

Cut instruments and parts ruthlessly and approach it with a minimalist's eye. Like writing a haiku: How few elements can you use to create an impression? Maybe a guitar part is carrying 90% of the groove and the drums only need to be a kick and a snare. Or maybe the guitar is covering the backbeat too, and you don't even need a snare!

Constantly ask yourself "What is the most important sensation in the record?" and then focus it by cutting out everything that gets in the way.

**6)** Hocketing. Pass the melody off between different instruments at different points in the song. Play it in different registers. Combine voices occasionally for special effect.

**7)** Tonal contrast. Dark instruments plus bright instruments. Distorted and clean together. Near vs. distant.

Elements that sound same-y will gel together and elements that contrast tonally will pop.

author: LAPhill
content:
Not a dumb question. The distortion on power chords creates an octave below the fundamental pitch, which helps make them feel well, powerful. For intervals other than a 5th, it's not an octave below but some other pitch, and so yeah, you're likely creating unpleasant harmonics outside of the key.

The dumbest, but easiest way to avoid that is to let the bass be the inversion's lowest note while the plays a 5th from the root note. Otherwise, you're looking at dialing back the distortion on those inversions, or on the tone as a whole, which isn't necessarily what's desired.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The method that sounds most transparent is hand editing (no digital stretching at all). You need to line up your edits so the wave form is perfect in the middle of each note, then use an equal gain cross fade at the edit point. This gives you the most transparency because there is no algorithmic stretching happening. 

It limits very slightly your options with timing because bass wave forms are long, so lining them up perfectly means you can only move the timing the length of each waveform. It's also time consuming compared to stretching.

If you are editing a DI that is then going through significant processing (amp sims and shit), you can sometimes get away with one of the stretching algorithms. Elastic audio is ok and usable sometimes, but I prefer Ableton's complex mode over everything else I've heard.

I try to avoid time stretching artifacts on lead vocals and bass instruments more than anything else (unless it's creatively interesting of course).

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames yeahhhh. watch the questlove video on youtube where he talks about d'angelo asking him to play crazy laid back and flammy too.

my general thought on timing is: behind the beat is more groovy and laid back (vocals, percussion, bass against the kick drum, etc) and ahead is intense and anxious (especially vocals).

there are many examples of groove being behind the beat as that's something people talk about a lot. definitely dive into that concept and play with laying different elements back off the grid.

but i LOVE talking about being ahead of the beat. purists complain that a lot of modern hip hop vocals are ahead of the beat and "off time." but when it's done well it makes the tracks SO exciting. lil durk, 21 savage, gucci, etc all have this excitement in some of the songs because the vocal are ahead. 

i've heard the argument that these guys are just amateurish in their skill. that might be true, but their natural groove and cadence works. also listen to kendrick on "Family Ties" where he goes in and out of being ahead of the beat and it sounds exciting as fuck when he does.

also "Icky Thump" by White Stripes is a song with vocals that are entirely ahead of the beat. clearly it's deliberate as jack white is a rhythmic genius (and the doubles are perfect). it adds this anxiety to the whole song that is SO dope.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Good question! 

As @cian riordan said, when you're perfectly lining up the waveform of any solid tone, you want equal gain so it doesn't give you a boost on the crossfade. This is for "correlated" signals where the waveform is lining up exactly. A bass guitar, the middle of a vocal note, a synth with a consistent waveform, etc.

When you're doing a crossfade on noise (breaths, sss's, ambience between drum hits, etc), you want equal power because these "uncorrelated" signals need a bit of boost around the crossfade for the perceived loudness to be the same.

You can check this by using a synth note or long vocal note, doing an edit to make it longer or shorter, lining up the waveforms perfectly, and doing a cross fade. You will find that equal power causes a volume bump. Equal gain will be smooth.

Do the same thing with white noise and this time equal power will be smooth, while equal gain will cause a volume dip.

author: peterlabberton
content: Under 40 hz? If we’re taking *that* low, in my experience usually kicks benefit from sitting just slightly above that range, especially in rock—somewhere around 50-60hz. Usually they sound punchier and less flabby with just a touch of the super low lows rolled off. Basses can move around a bit more, obviously, but I also find that usually even if you have a fundamental around or below 40 hz, the first harmonic an octave above is usually what you’re actually interested in. Also it’s very song/arrangement/tempo (!) dependent! A slower tempo or less busy kick pattern or song arrangement will let you get away with loads more super sub stuff. Faster patterns will just sound like flabby mush with tons of sub.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve been thinking about @Joel "Roomie" Berghult‘s question re: mixing as you since he asked it. I think what Rauirí says about not knowing what we’re doing while we’re doing it is really true, so I’ve just been trying to dissect my process in my brain, away from the computer.  I think it comes down to 2 things for me. 

Here are my thoughts:


1) Choosing Sounds. 

In addition to vibe & genre & emotional intent, each instrument or sample that you pick covers a certain area of the overall picture. Knowing where that part is going to go in the overall arrangement changes how much hi end or low end or wetness (etc.) you want. It also steers performances. 

2) Actually Mixing As You Go 

Once a part is recorded, do a quick adjustment so that you hear closer to a finished product. This helps you make better choices about what else needs to be added, (or not added,) and will likely inspire the next step.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you know your way around a synthesizer, Massive X and Serum 2 are both heavy hitters that cover all of my bases. 

Sonically, Massive X has a "warmer" voicing and has all of NI's amazing effect algorithms built into it. Everything sounds incredible and is dripping with character. It's absurdly capable, but the interface may be overwhelming at first. It can be a lot to get oriented on. It's impossible for this thing to sound "cold". The preset library is less bass music/EDM and more balanced. NI offers a lot of genre-themed expansions. If you like programming sequenced/heavily automated one-button patches Massive X is king.

Serum is on the "cold" side, but just as capable of "warmer" sounds. The sonics and DSP are clear as a bell. Stellar. It's more intuitive to program and the feature set is an embarrassment of riches. It's absurd how much functionality Steve and team crammed into it. Absolutely absurd. If you want to do EDM and bass music, it's the king and it's preset library leans towards that. I still cannot believe that they *gave* it away to Serum 1 users.

Both excel at cinematic and over the top. If you're looking for the "classic" sound, I'd lean Massive X.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
Im pretty much always messing with the length of kick, snare and hat trying to get them to fit in the grove better, you can make some unlikely pairs work when you do this.

Also always messing with the order in which transients are hitting on downbeats, nudging certain drums slightly before or after others can make things mesh together real nice. Typically the higher pitched/attacky things like hi hats come earlier than the sub kicks for example but experiment with it and see what sounds good. A song where this is really obvious is say it right by nelly furtado, listen to the way the layers are stacked on the downbeats of the chorus. Side note, when you're doing this, think of everything with a transient on that downbeat as a percussion instrument.

author: Deleted User
content:
usually saw/buzz basses can’t have much perceived subs without filtering because of the amount of upper harmonics. with shorter saw bass- I usually tend to favor the upper area for punch and get the low subs from kick and if I need lengths in the lows I double it with a sub or electric bass and not use the sub from the saw bass. on saw bass with longer sustain- I like to do band pass filtering (take out subs and filter out the sizzlely highs) and use a separate sub bass in the middle and use saw bass that spreads out on the sides. 

I wouldn’t do significant boost lows on saw bass, I find it just messes with the character of the sound too much

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Yes! Honestly when you stack the fuck outta airy vocals you can make them a LOT darker than you would a single vocal. All the air sums pretty violently. Also eq individual tracks AND busses. Once you get an idea of how her particular voice stacks, you can eq on the way in and save some time. 
3rdly, getting the performance as close to perfect as you can instead of tuning or auto-aligning will do a lot for the stereo field and vitality of the overall sound. 

If you’re just talking about the lead vocal, Multiband or Dyanmic Eq is your friend, but absolutely CRUSH that LV with something that has inherent low end saturation like Devil Loc (at like a 2) or a UAD 175-B. That’ll help balance the overall eq of the vocal better than just an additive eq/saturation. 

I know that’s a lot but hopefully that’s helpful!

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Honestly I almost always start a live bass with UAD’s Ampeg B15. It’s ballsy as hell and there’s a lot of options for cabs, presets are all super useful. Once I’m there I hit a decap or other saturation plug with a mix knob and dial in the upper mids to “growl” a la @Slow Hand’s CLA, the I compress the fuck out of it. Depending on how much thump or how smooth I want it, I usually go with either a UAD fairchild 660 or DBX160. Dyanmic eq Side chained to the kick right at the kik fundamental, and bobs your Fucken uncle. Usually. 

Another trick that helps me usually is a static eq dip just above the fundamentals. Clearly out those lows usually helps the bottom and growl speak better for me. 

That being said- a poorly recorded or performed bass isn’t just warfare, it’s heartbreak warfare. 😯😬🤪

author: Deleted User
content: Sooo, on the recording side of things: if you’re going DI, most interfaces do not have a high enough input impedance to do passive pickups justice, especially if you want a decent amount of low end. Guitar pickups sound good with 1-2MOhm(the input impedance of a good tube amp), but if I want really clear modern low end that can compete with 808s, then I’ve had the best results with around 10MOhm on passive bass pickups. Another important thing is a transistor-based active DI will not get you a full low end. You will end up re-amping or using amp emulations etc. Octal tubes(the type of tubes IN the B15) will. Octal tubes have a lot more body(think U47, for example) and will get you there much much quicker. I have a Sarno V8, which isn’t perfect, but sounds clean, “finished” and modern from the get-go. No compression or emulations needed. It’s also comparatively affordable, so totally worth every penny.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think the best thing you can do when learning a synthesizer is to pick just one or two and really take the time to learn them inside and out. There's so much overlap between the feature set and if you can get very intuitive with one synth you'll go so much farther.

Back in the day I bought NI's *Komplete* bundle and it was just way too many new instruments too fast. Too many options. I never got to know any of them very well. Most synths have all of the same features that you'll want, but there's still a learning curve for every single one that you have to get over before you can be really expressive. I wish it were as easy as picking up a guitar or a horn where everything is standardized and lies in the same place. But that's part of what makes synths great: Their plasticity.

Nowadays the only synths I reach for (unless I need a very specific sound) are *Massive X*, *Razor*, and my Moog Sub 37. The first two are very different and don't share many features. I use the Moog when I don't want to be tethered to my computer. Limiting my available tools has been a net benefit for me.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Synth detectives, assemble!

author: Will Trotman
content:
In addition to the diamonds like Noah said, just root notes chugging away or playing 8th notes can be helpful and non invasive if chords or power chords feel too informative. Octaves can be a cool halfway point. A lot of songs seem to have room for the clean “dinky” sort of electric parts (sometimes slightly melodic or sometimes just hanging out on a single note).

If it’s a matter of filling space, something that helped me on a pop track the other day was making a second track for echoes of the lead vocal where you can low pass it pretty hard and delay / verb it out.

I often find myself introducing subtle sub basses later in the song, potentially doubling electric bass with synth bass, maybe layering snares to be fatter in later choruses. Then playing with some subtle percussion elements like triangle, clave, wood blocks, to differentiate later choruses.

author: Daniel Ross
content: I feel like groove is so subjective so we’re probably all wrong and all right to some degree…but I almost never let my bass be off grid. I always find the impact lessened when I do. Something about a lack of confidence in the low end makes me like the song less. There are exceptions but they are rare imo. And I hardly ever let the down beats of transitions be off grid too. I usually want the sections to be obvious. I also start with going behind the beat first. I have also recently in the last year or so found that if I start with getting the very basic part of the groove right first, I am less likely to overcrowd my production. So before I put hats in, I’ll just put in snare and kick and try and find the groove with just those 2 elements (unless there is some other clear rhythmic element at play) but I feel like if you can’t feel the groove with just the kick and (snare/clap/perc) then it’s not there.

author: Slow Hand
content:
@wilhelmjosephk Yeah. Sometimes sounds are such a fluke of using a particular processor in a certain way that you’d be lucky to reproduce it on another source or patch, even if you know how you got there originally (shoutout *Trash 2*).

That said, I believe I’m hearing three (maybe 4) layers that could very easily be overdubs, rather than played as a single patch:

1. The dark, (relatively) clean, bass component.

2. The midrangey portamento Prophet-type layer that’s most intelligible.

2a. The blown-out grungy layer that could easily be Layer #2 slammed into a tape emulator with very skewed biasing.

3. A 100% wet reverb/echo channel. It seems to mostly be fed by layer #2.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone have any rules-of-thumb that they rely on when programming groove?

Things like "I like my bass notes to be ___ in relation to the kick because..." or "I put my hats (blank) the snare because..." or "My (instrument) is 100% locked to the grid all of the time." 

Of course, everything is context dependent, so we're talking generalities here. But if you make nothing but trap music or lo-fi beats it would be good to mention that as well, for context.

I'm curious to know what approaches everyone else has arrived at. For better or worse, I like to start with a blank slate each time and it ends up being an exploratory process for me every time.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I asked a similar question a while ago, and @oaklandmatt had a great answer basically to the effect of: 
Something rushing ahead adds energy or anxiousness (a punk bass line or fast trap hihats, maybe a rock guitar solo)
Something late adds groove/swagger (Lofi hip hop snare, a lazy vocal, a funky bass line)
I think that’s a really cut and dry way to view it; but what you said obviously applies, every context is different.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah its very case by case. as far as groove in relation to other elements. I've had guitars recorded loosely toa click and worked the groove around that - lining up the downbeats of the drums/bass  with the guitars even if it's a bit early or late. that was for a more indie type of joint. and for something more trap /modern hip hop, I've nudged bass notes or samples to get them to either sync w drums up for impact  or nudge slightly off to hype of of pull back the energy in the groove. 

as far as programming. I'll play with forward swing and dragging notes a lot if I'm going for a more real/dynamic feel when programming. keeping in mind that if the goal is trying to stay "on time" any fwd swing that might happen at the start of a phrase will be compensated with some drag  after or vice versa.  keeping velocities in mind w drum hits + linking it to a filter env so that harder hits have more high end and softer hits end up a bit rounder.

adding subtle layers that are similar   to the main drums but occupy a different texture or tone  in dif  sections to thicken up the groove or automate the attack /sustain of certain elements thru diff sections to help shift the listener  focus throughout

author: Slow Hand
content:
(Ok. Now I'm starting to run with this train of thought. Now would be a good time to step off if you've gotten what you need.)

I don't want this to sound like the end-all be-all. One of my absolute favorites is James Brown, and there is no way that some of his songs would hold up to the level of scrutiny I'm describing. And those records *kill*. It's all vibe. It's vibe all the way down, bebe. Not a chord change in sight. Barely a melody in some cases. And that's alright.

So what did James do? More often than not James would get all of his band (real jazz killers) in the studio and he would sing the parts to them one by one and allow them to input their own feel.

He'd start with the drummer and have them play a pattern that James was feeling. Once the drummer was jamming on that he would move on to the bass player and sing them an idea. Once the bass player had that germ of an idea they would continue to jam on it with the drummer, refining and adding their own thing. Then James would move on to the horns, and so on, and so on.

While James could be dictatorial and (from the perspective of music education) the least technically qualified person in the room he had *vision*. 

If the song has a strong identity you can give your players a good (non-technical) prompt and they can interpret that through their own sensibilities. You can describe a mood, or a scene, or an abstract sensation.

R. Kelly once said (I'm paraphrasing): "RnB is supposed to feel like the best moment of your *life*." That simple description conveys so much about the feel, the pleasure, and the joy that he is looking for in his music. It also excludes a lot of possibilities as well. If you can give your players a prompt like *that* then you can get everyone aligned on the same wavelength and it will carry you so much further without the need to dictate parts.

----

author: Zach Hughes
content: I think it’s a question of trade offs and the pitfalls and benefits of varying choices. I don’t have a specific question but am more curious to discuss the topic  and hear other folks experience. Could go many diff directions.. how do we facilitate those ‘special’ moments with session players? Which I like the idea of getting the piece you know you want or need first and then playing the rest of the time. Or how to communicate and prevent really good players from over powering a song and doing too much? For this project I chose to leave a lot of room for the players to play and write their own parts, but I also needed to reel them in a little bit and simplify what was happening. Even then when I dug through the tracks I had to mute certain fills, take a simpler pass of the keys to let the bass do it’s thing or vice versa. This also makes me consider the question: when do you let a song suggest to you when something special needs to happen?

author: Ross Fortune
content:
From a cursory Synthtopia scan:

"So it seems that Luis Fernando Zepeda is part of the Organist generation of 60s-70s Mexico City with others like Evaristo Enriquez or Juan Torres.
This technique was “invented” by Tito Enriquez but perfected by Ernesto “Hill” Gil Olvera, whom was blind, and recorded LPs under the advertising that he played “the Organ that Talks!”

I found on a random blog that the drawbar configuration was something like this, you started with:
A = 88 8000 000 00
E = 80 8080 000 00
I = 80 0080 000 00
O = 80 8000 000 00
U = 80 0000 000 00

And you worked them with your left hand as you played with your right hand and play bass with with left foot and expression with right foot. It is a Hammond X66"


There's lots of Ernesto Gil Olvera stuff on YT, but I (and my nephew) don't like it is as much as this Luis Fernando Zepeda track. Can't find anything else by him unfortunately.

author: Deleted User
content:
So on tiny differences- I’ve seen you talk about this here every now and then. But at what point does it matter and at what point does it not matter? 

Does it really matter whether I used Warm47 or real 47 if it does its thing and makes you feel things? And does it really matter to care about things like that if it costs so much more to get a real 47, if it does then at what point does it start becoming a worthwhile investment other than for a self satisfaction? 

I’m in the camp of just buy a sub 1k mic/guitars that does its thing. 1 - because it would be a ridiculous decision to spend more money than that with what I make now 2 - It’s case by cases but a lot of times when I hear comparison it’s not really a matter of “it’s better” but more so it’s exactly that thing or that sound we know and like. I’m sure there is value in that, but when does that become actually valuable and when does it become just trivial difference?

Anyone have any tips on working with new artists/producers with no filter? Like where they NEED to try out every idea they have, even if it's not good, or if it's a bad time (ie we're tracking guitars and they stop everyone to try out a (bad) bass idea).

author: spectrummasters

author: Slow Hand
content:
You may already be aware, but you can get very different textures by playing with the LFO shape on the tremolo. 

The bass is more of a sine/triangle shape while those vocal samples have harder edges, closer to a square wave. The square wave modulating volume at high rates will give you that "ripple" I think you may be hearing.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Other strategies for re-vamping the feel and arrangement:
1. Trying putting instruments in different registers (move the bass up/down an octave).
2. Play the song in a neutral form like only piano and vocals and listen for what it might suggest.
3. Substitute instruments (Ex: bowed bass instead of electric bass).
4. Try a different key.
5. Try half-time. Try double-time.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
And not just for making things incrementally better, but for solving problems as well.

I recently was mixing a song with a young mixer who I gave my session to. I heard a very subtle low and thump after two particular downbeat and we could not figure out what it was. We solo'ed some groups and then I remembered that he had replicated my autotune settings on the bass guitar (he had a slightly different version). I know from lots of tuning experience that different modes will occasionally cause different types of artifacts. So we solo'ed the bass, switched from "modern" (his default) to "classic" and it was solved.

author: longstoryshort
content:
one of my earlier experiences writing for other people (ghost producing for a few DJs) in that same kinda lane, future bass ish

i used to produce before i would *write* sometimes, and the energy would just get sucked right out of the room

as soon i opened serum they'd say oh we're not getting a record done today

that moment really hurt me at that time, but later on i realized it was true - it's always the true criticism that really hits, right?

so i made adjustments by building out my sounds/library/synth patches in advance, so when sessions came up i would be able to just fire in 90% of the way done sounds.

when the song was written then i'd finish up the sounds and do the tweaking and the session had so much momentum it didn't take long to finish.

records got done, money was made, everyone was happier.
